title: 109_hr3706
content:
The National Independent Inquiry Commission on Disaster Preparedness and Response (referred to as the Commission) is established. The purpose of the Commission is outlined in the Act. The National Independent Inquiry Commission on Disaster Preparedness and Response, known as the Commission, is established to examine, evaluate, and report on the readiness and preparedness of Federal, State, and local governments and agencies to respond to the effects of Hurricane Katrina and future disasters of all kinds, sizes, and scopes. The Commission is tasked with evaluating the readiness of governments to respond to disasters, including Hurricane Katrina, and assessing the effectiveness of rescue operations and coordination between different levels of government. They will also investigate the adequacy of the Federal response to Hurricane Katrina and report on the government's failure to prepare and respond adequately. The Commission's composition is outlined in Section 3. The Commission, as outlined in Section 3, consists of 10 members appointed by various leaders from the Democratic and Republican parties. The President appoints the chairman, the House leader appoints the vice chairman, and other members are appointed by senior party leaders from both the Senate and House of Representatives. The Commission, established with 10 members appointed by leaders from the Democratic and Republican parties, has specific guidelines for member appointments, including party affiliation restrictions and qualifications. All members must be appointed by December 15, 2005, and the Commission must convene promptly after appointments. After its initial meeting, the Commission will meet when called by the Chairperson or a majority of members. A quorum of eight members is required for meetings. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission will meet as called by the Chairperson or majority of members, with a quorum of eight members required for meetings. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission's functions include investigating the effectiveness and efficiency of Federal preparation and response to Hurricane Katrina, identifying lessons learned from the event, and evaluating government structures and policies related to disaster preparedness. The Commission is tasked with investigating the effectiveness and efficiency of Federal preparation and response to natural disasters. This includes evaluating mitigation, flood protection, early warning systems, evacuation procedures, life-saving techniques, law enforcement, public health, infrastructure, commerce, and telecommunications. The Commission will submit reports to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for improving organization, coordination, planning, and management arrangements. The Commission will also investigate telecommunications, environmental protection, and other relevant areas in the public and private sectors for its inquiry. The Commission has powers to investigate various sectors including telecommunications and environmental protection. The Commission has the authority to conduct hearings, take testimony, and subpoena witnesses and documents for the purpose of carrying out its duties under the Act. Subpoenas can be served by designated individuals and enforced by the United States district court in cases of non-compliance. The Commission has the authority to issue orders for individuals to testify or produce evidence, with non-compliance punishable as contempt of court. Additional enforcement measures apply for witnesses failing to comply. Closed meetings can be held by the Commission as needed. The Commission may close meetings if national security is at risk. It can enter contracts and request information from federal agencies. The General Services Administration must assist the Commission. General Services provides administrative support to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. Other departments and agencies can also offer services, funds, and support as authorized by law. The Commission can accept gifts and use the United States mails. The Commission, subcommittees, members, and agents of the United States have the authority to take actions authorized by the Commission. SEC. 6. STAFF OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. Additional staff may be appointed as needed without following certain civil service laws. Staff may be paid up to the equivalent of level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission can appoint individuals as employees under specific sections of the United States Code. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their regular employment rights. The Commission can also procure consultant services at specified rates. SEC. 7. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES.

Each Commission member may receive compensation up to the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for a level IV position under section 5315 of title 5, United States Code. They are also entitled to travel expenses, including per diem, while performing Commission duties.

SEC. 8. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. SEC. 8. The Commission members and staff will be provided with appropriate security clearances to access classified information, following existing procedures and requirements. No individual ineligible for such clearance will be granted access. The Commission will submit an initial report to the President and Congress within 1 year of its first meeting, followed by a final report within 6 months of the initial report. The Commission and its authorities will terminate 60 days after the final report is submitted. The Commission may use the 60-day period after its final report to conclude activities, including testifying to Congress and disseminating the final report. Authorization of appropriations for the Commission under this Act is set at $3,000,000, with funds remaining available until expended.
